summary: This is a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense counsel to Judge Loretta A. Preska requesting reconsideration of an order to unseal Maxwell's deposition transcripts and to commence contempt proceedings for violation of a protective order. The letter argues the government improperly obtained the confidential deposition transcripts, used them to indict Maxwell for perjury, and that unsealing would prejudice her right to a fair trial. This is a court filing from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team requesting reconsideration of a decision to unseal deposition transcripts. It argues that Maxwell reasonably relied on a protective order when giving deposition testimony, and that providing the transcripts to the government for perjury charges violated legal precedent (Martindell). The document suggests a 'perjury trap' was set for Maxwell.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the deposition transcripts at issue. Her defense team is arguing that the protective order covering her depositions was violated when transcripts were provided to the government, leading to perjury charges against her.

persons.name: Loretta A. Preska
persons.context: The judge presiding over the civil case (Giuffre v. Maxwell) who issued the July 23, 2020 ruling to unseal deposition transcripts. The letter is addressed to her requesting reconsideration.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Held a press conference after Maxwell's arrest, commenting on Maxwell's credibility and expressing opinions about her guilt, specifically referencing alleged lies in her deposition.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in Maxwell's criminal case. She admonished counsel about extrajudicial comments to protect Maxwell's right to a fair trial, a point cited by Maxwell's defense.

persons.name: Mr. Edwards
persons.context: Plaintiff's attorney who made public comments calling Maxwell 'a main facilitator' of Epstein's crimes who 'started the whole thing' after her arrest.

persons.name: Ms. McCawley
persons.context: Plaintiff's attorney who praised prosecutors after Maxwell's arrest and opined that Maxwell would 'remain in prison for the remainder of her life' and was 'the central figure'.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to in the context of the criminal activities Maxwell is alleged to have facilitated. The document mentions relentless negative media coverage about him and Maxwell.

persons.name: Ty Gee
persons.context: Attorney from the law firm Haddon, Morgan and Foreman who is listed as counsel for Ms. Maxwell and the sender of this letter to Judge Preska.

persons.name: Judge Sirica
persons.context: Referenced from the Nixon v. Warner Communications case as an example of a judge who denied release of materials to protect defendants' rights on appeal.

persons.name: Judge Weinstein
persons.context: Referenced from the In re New York Times Co. case for denying a media motion to unseal papers to protect defendants' fair trial rights.

persons.name: Judge Sweet
persons.context: Previously denied a motion by Maxwell's team related to information about criminal investigations prior to her deposition.

persons.name: Doe 1
persons.context: An anonymous plaintiff whose deposition transcripts are also subject to the sealing/unsealing dispute alongside Maxwell's.

connections.description: Maxwell is alleged to have 'assisted, facilitated, and contributed' to Epstein's abuse of minors, according to the government's superseding indictment referenced in the document.
Ty Gee, of Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, is identified as counsel for Ms. Maxwell and is writing this letter on her behalf.
Strauss, as Acting U.S. Attorney, prosecuted Maxwell and made public statements about her alleged guilt based on the deposition testimony.
Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case and has issued warnings to counsel to protect Maxwell's right to a fair trial.
Both are identified as plaintiff's counsel who made public comments about Maxwell's guilt following her arrest.
Both are parties in the same civil litigation, and the sealing of both their deposition transcripts is being contested together in this filing.

events.title: Arrest of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The government staged a dramatic, forced entry at dawn into Maxwell's home and arrested her, one day after she filed a reply in the civil case.

events.title: Superseding Indictment Filed
events.description: The government filed a superseding indictment alleging Maxwell assisted in Epstein's abuse of minors and committed perjury in her 2016 deposition.

events.title: Court's Unsealing Ruling
events.description: Judge Preska ruled that transcripts of Maxwell's April 2016 deposition and Doe 1's deposition should be unsealed in their entirety (with non-party names redacted).

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell's Deposition
events.description: Maxwell gave deposition testimony in the civil case. The transcript was designated 'Confidential' but was later obtained by the government and cited in the perjury charges.

events.title: Court Order on Protective Order Violation
events.description: The Court expressed being 'troubled' that plaintiff's successor counsel, Cooper & Kirk, received protected discovery materials from former counsel Boies Schiller Flexner.

events.title: Court Order on Investigation Materials
events.description: The court ordered the plaintiff to turn over any materials related to criminal investigations, except for statements made by the plaintiff to law enforcement.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell's Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was deposed the day after the court order. She did not assert her 5th Amendment privilege, relying on the protective order and the plaintiff's failure to disclose an ongoing criminal investigation.

events.title: Court Ruling on Unsealing
events.description: The court issued a ruling to unseal the deposition transcripts of Ghislaine Maxwell and Doe 1, which this filing is requesting be reconsidered.

locations: 500 Pearl Street, New York, NY 10007 (United States District Court, Southern District of New York)
Denver, Colorado (Location of Haddon, Morgan and Foreman law firm)
keyFacts: Maxwell's defense alleges a serious violation of a protective order, claiming the government improperly obtained her confidential deposition transcripts and used them to secure a perjury indictment against her.
The defense argues the deposition was used as a 'perjury trap,' noting the plaintiff had previously claimed involvement in an ongoing criminal investigation while withholding related documents.
The letter cites Maxwell's arrest on July 2, 2020, and a superseding indictment on July 8, 2020, as new facts justifying reconsideration of the unsealing order to protect her right to a fair trial.
The protective order specifically excluded a 'law enforcement' exception, a point negotiated by the parties, which Maxwell's counsel claims the government violated.
The defense requests the court commence contempt proceedings against those who violated the protective order and to stay any unsealing to allow for an appeal to the Second Circuit.

The filing argues the government circumvented legal precedent (Martindell v. International Telephone & Telegraph Corp.) by obtaining sealed deposition transcripts to charge Ghislaine Maxwell with perjury, suggesting a 'perjury trap' was set.

Ghislaine Maxwell's defense claims she reasonably relied on a protective order when giving intimate personal details in her deposition, and that the Second Circuit's ruling in Brown v. Maxwell supports keeping such information confidential.
The plaintiff allegedly attached the full deposition transcripts to court submissions and leaked them or caused them to be leaked to the government, leading to the perjury charges against Maxwell.
A prior motion by Maxwell to obtain information about any criminal investigation was denied by Judge Sweet, and the plaintiff later produced no such materials before her deposition.
